title: Labor to back big stick energy law
text:
Despite the backing of some Nationals, the government will not countenance this.

Labor, which opposed the legislation before the election on the basis it was bad law that could hamper energy sector investment, will support it so long as there is no prospect of a state-owned asset being privatised if forcibly divested.

The government has given an assurance that if any such loophole exists, it will be closed.

The bill has already been significantly softened from the version that was shelved before the election in order to reduce the backlash from business and ensure parliamentary passage.

The biggest change is that the Federal Court, not the treasurer of the day, will decide whether a company should have its assets forcibly divested upon a recommendation of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

Also, the laws will expire in 2025 and the powers will apply only to the conduct of energy companies in the wholesale market.

It still, however, contains a provision that enables the government to compel companies to supply electricity at a fixed price, quantity and duration for up to three years.

Labor still faces internal ructions over its positions on the free trade deals.

Advertisement

After Labor indicated last week it would pass the legislation after securing a handful of concessions, a group of Left unions, including the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union, United Voice, the Community and Public Sector Union and the Australian Services Union, wrote to MPs seeking to change their minds.

Caucus may discuss the legislation today but Labor may defer a decision for another week. It managed to secure some concessions on the Investor-State Dispute Settlement clauses which allow a foreign company to sue if disadvantaged by a government decision.

Labor will try to implement protections against the importation of foreign workers without having to test the labour market first.

"Unless Labor can secure amendments to the proposed agreements which give expression to these important commitments to the Australian community, we ask that all Labor members of Parliament vote against legislation that will damage or undermine Australian workplace laws, access to employment opportunities and the economic welfare of our communities," the unions wrote.
description: Shadow cabinet is expected to endorse the big stick legislation regulating energy companies.
